title: Will Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador win the 2018 Mexican presidential election?

Mexican presidential frontrunner Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador extended his lead to nearly 17 points over his nearest rival ahead of the July 1 vote, according to a poll published on Sunday. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mexico-election-poll/mexican-leftist-frontrunner-widens-lead-for-presidency-poll-idUSKBN1J700K?il=0
No Mexican presidential election candidate has won more than 50% of the vote since 1988. Current polling shows Obrador with twice the support of his closest rival.
The last two election winners took home less than 50% of the vote. Polls currently show obrador out front by

News AMLO is "moving towards the center" have dominated the news this week. Anaya's camp went as far as to accuse AMLO of making a deal with PRI and Pena Nieto not to prosecute Pena for corruption. Bloomberg reported AMLO was considering Guillermo Ortiz, Santiago Levy for cabinet positions if elected. Ortiz was finance minister under Zedillo; he's been Mexico's ambassador to the IMF, chairman of Banorte, chief at Banco de Mexico... That would be quite  turn for AMLO but a move said to address jitters in the markets.   Investors are said to have started running away from Mexican stocks as AMLO pulls ahead.  Mexico's benchmark stock index plummeted 7.6% in May, biggest one-month decline since Feb '09. The exchange-traded fund, EWW, plunged 13.4%, largest loss since 2011
Because of the various reports and the Bloomberg poll tracker which shows his prospects have been steadily increasing since March 2018.
Shifting higher in line with AMLOs polls.

There are a couple of other rivals with a significant share of the vote, and it would seem a significant challenge for him to get >50% of the vote https://www.as-coa.org/articles/poll-tracker-mexicos-2018-presidential-election .  Barring some surprise, it seems unlikely he woudl lose the election.

Still skeptical AMLO will win this time around. But top scholars dedicated to Lat American politics, economics at major US universities have started to express resignation at an AMLO win. They know these countries well, their everyday job is to study trends and changes there. Still digging deep on this one and at the edge of my seat. NOTE:  The MORENA Party founded by AMLO currently has 28 congressmen out of 500, zero senators, no governors, and 30 mayors out of 2,474. Still the Consulta Mitofsky poll projects MORENA will take control of both the chamber of deputies and the senate, and 4 governorships including the capital.  I had to research this one several times to try to make sense of it. It's quite a feat for a country like Mexico where PRI, PAN, PRD are the major parties. 
A good explanation of how AMLO's movement grew is that from 2006-2011, he took the road to visit ALL of Mexico’s 2,438 municipalities "to plant a seed for his Morena party" and left an established movement in each.  He first established MORENA's a non-government organization with the mission of promoting his policies and political views. The NGO grew enough to convince Mexico’s 3 left-wing parties to join in. UNDECIDED:  Most polls out do not include the undecided nor percentages of those who chose not to respond. In this agregrate of most reliable, major polls in the country, figures of 30%-38% of undecided are cited

His ability to challenge for the election is a reflection of this. But it's easy for me to have opinions because I don't have property or financial interests in Mexico. I have faith he would treat everyone fairly.

Bloomberg's poll tracker has AMLO at 52.8%; Anaya 25.7%; Meade 19.1%.  In 2006, AMLO led polls for TWO YEARS, then Felipe Calderon took the lead in April and May, won by half a percentage point. But it's June, 27 days to go.

Updating yes probabilities up slightly based on recent polls

Obrador ran twice before and lost. Last time won just under 32%. He is clearly the front runner at this stage but there has to some chance he de-rails for some reason or other, or as another forecaster reminds, simply has ill health or some other such reason why he cannot win. So a small probability of ‘no’ is warranted. To win more than 50% of the vote would seem to require a really substantial shift in voters’ views on Obrador and I don’t know enough to make that claim.

Let’s cover the 4%. Random things can happen from death to opponent boosting events. The time is running down for this to have a high probability. The are several factors that lead to my 85% yes with <50% . First, the reference of prior elections indicates that <50% has been the norm. Second, the trend in thes base probabilities is down. I can’t isolate why, but I believe it to be worth taking into account. Third, the global populist movement (Macron, 5*Movement, Sariza, Brexit), even in LatAm (Bolsonaro), suggests that there remains a non-negligible probability that AMLO may get more than 50%. There is no indication that this phenomenon is diminishing in influence. Lastly, NAFTA is an uncertainty that currently appears to be resolved under the new administration. Thus, AMLO can leverage this populist platform opportunity, another reason not to overly discount yes >50%.
Leading in the polls does not mean more than fifty percent of the voters

1) Base Rate for past 5 Presidential elections 
Nieto - 38%
Calderon - 36.38%
Fox - 43%
Zedillo - 48%
Salinas - 50% 2) Obrador won roughly 36% of the vote in the 2006 election against Calderon although he challenged the results and lost
3) Polling for April - May 4 (Average of 11 polls)
Obrador - average 45.6%
Anaya - average 25.72%
Meade - average 18.22%
Zavala - average 4.8%
Rodriguez - average 3%
4) Of the 5 major candidates in the race, Zavala (Calderon's wife) pulled out on 5/16. While her name remains on the ballot, her votes are expected to transfer to Anaya. If the "mafia of power" (a term used by Obrador) can't stop him from winning, they will do what they can to weaken his mandate.

Taking a long, hard look at the campaign and it's difficult to believe AMLO would win, but polls give him quite a wide margin. Margarita Zavala quit the race this week, improving, somewhat, chances for Anaya and Meade.  As the Trump victory and others recently showed, we can't look at polls alone. It's the third run for AMLO thus trying to figure out how is the country ready or more willing to embrace him as leader? What has changed this time around?  Will Mexicans elect AMLO among the level of violence in the country?  This year alone, 91 pre-candidates from all parties have been murdered, over 200 assaulted, in the run up to Mexico's regional and national elections.  It's a panorama that tends to favor hard-liners.  Then again, the staggering violence, is the elephant in the room in the campaign trail. The picture I see of Mexico from the outside, the political system in power, would say AMLO is not going to win in the end, but the election system itself (one round, more than two candidates) gives AMLO the odds.   Biggest difference I see this time seems to be the people AMLO is running against, they're much less charismatic, are failing to inspire impassioned following.  Meade is running a great campaign but the stain of the  PRI and EPN's government may be too much for him to overcome.   In 2012, aside from the country seeking to change from PAN and what was seen as Pres. Calderon's failed war against drug gangs and violence, Peña Nieto was hugely popular, sold as a quasi soap opera star. EPN received 38.4%, AMLO 31.6%.  In 2006, Calderon was declared the winner over AMLO with a difference of a bit over half of a percentage point. AMLO accused Calderon of fraud, protested for months, refusing to accept election results. The PAN candidate, Josefina Mota, got 25.4% and a green party candidate 2.3%.  In 2000, Fox got 42.5%, Labastida 36.1%, and Cardenas 16.6%. 
Going back to my point of the difference in the candidates AMLO is running against this time around,  in comparison to the people who have run in the last 16 years, Peña Nieto, Calderon, Fox, Labastida, Cardenas, and AMLO himself all fit the bill of "presidential". (Peña Nieto aside, all these names have been iconic in some way) Being "presidential" is something Anaya (who is mocked as looking like cartoon character Chicken Little) seems to be lacking.  I think Anaya will lose on insisting on wearing a down vest to look more down to earth. lol

Meade may have an even a weaker image, but that is only until he speaks.  In these times of social media and short attention spans and only reading headlines, it's a tough battle.  Meade tends to lose the masses  with his technocrat lingo, can't speak "populism" but he has an impressive program of proposals and experience.  If there are surprises, my take is they would be related to Meade.   I don't think the odds of AMLO getting over 50% are good.  He lost to EPN by 7 pts in 2012.  No candidate since Salinas de Gortari beat Cuauhtemoc Cardenas in 1988 has received over 50% in a presidential election in Mexico.  Will keep looking at trends as the campaign continues.
The renewed violence gives impetus for voters to give AMLO a mandate.

Mexican self esteem and pride will give the election to Obrador.  The only question is the size of the turn out.  The higher the turn out the greater margin of victory for Obrador.  The results will make for an interesting political dynamic between the United States of Mexico and the United States of America in the remainder of 2018.
